title: Fournier’s Gangrene
diagnosis_topic: Life-threatening necrotizing infection of the perineum
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with diabetes and alcohol use disorder presents with scrotal pain and swelling for two days. He is febrile and appears ill; foul odor emanates from the genital region. How would you proceed?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 90/50 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 39 °C, SpO₂ 95%.
Edematous, erythematous scrotum with patches of black necrotic skin and crepitus; foul discharge present.
WBC 25 K/µL, lactate 5 mmol/L, creatinine 2.0 mg/dL; glucose 350 mg/dL.
Carbapenem plus clindamycin and vancomycin started immediately.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident aggressively resuscitates with fluids and starts vasopressors
If resident consults surgery for emergent debridement
dynamic_flow.reply: Extensive debridement of scrotal, perineal, and lower abdominal fascia performed; testicles spared if viable.
Infection spreads rapidly with high mortality.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers fecal and urinary diversion
dynamic_flow.reply: Diverting colostomy and suprapubic catheter may be necessary for wound healing and hygiene.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about hyperbaric oxygen therapy
dynamic_flow.reply: May be used as adjunct but does not replace surgery and antibiotics.
ICU care, serial debridements, glycemic control, nutritional support, and wound reconstruction planning.
Necrosis recurs at wound edges, requiring additional debridement.
Plans staged reconstruction with skin grafting or flaps once infection is controlled.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses risk factor modification
dynamic_flow.reply: Control of diabetes, abstinence from alcohol, and smoking cessation recommended.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of Fournier’s gangrene and rapid progression
Aggressive resuscitation and initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Consideration of fecal and urinary diversion for wound care
Postoperative critical care and risk factor management
